name: Carpenter's rule problem
summary: The Carpenter's Rule problem refers to two main geometric problems: whether a polygonal chain can be continuously and smoothly "straightened" without self-intersection, and finding the minimum length into which a chain of hinged segments can be folded (the "folding problem"). The "straightening" problem has been solved, proving any open polygonal chain can be flattened. The "folding" problem, which is NP-complete, asks if a ruler can be folded into a given length.
head: a collection of non-intersecting polygonal arcs and simple polygons in the plane has rigid edges and hinged vertices (a linkage)
tail: then there exists a continuous motion (an expansive motion) of the linkage that preserves edge lengths, avoids self-intersections, and results in all arcs becoming straight and all polygons becoming convex.
